title: 113_hr556
content: The Act titled "Refundable Child Tax Credit Eligibility Verification Reform Act of 2013" requires a Social Security Number to claim the refundable portion of the Child Tax Credit. The Act "Refundable Child Tax Credit Eligibility Verification Reform Act of 2013" mandates the inclusion of a taxpayer's social security number on tax returns to claim certain credits, with exceptions for joint returns and high tentative minimum tax amounts. The Act mandates including social security numbers on tax returns to claim credits, with exceptions for joint returns and high tentative minimum tax amounts. Amendments address omissions of correct social security numbers and effective date for taxable years. SEC. 3 imposes restrictions on taxpayers who improperly claimed the refundable portion of the Child Tax Credit in a prior year. SEC. 3 imposes restrictions on taxpayers who improperly claimed the refundable portion of the Child Tax Credit in a prior year by disallowing the credit for 10 taxable years after a final determination of fraudulent or reckless claims. Taxpayers who improperly claimed the refundable portion of the Child Tax Credit may face restrictions for 10 taxable years after a final determination of fraudulent or reckless claims. The amendment restricts the allowance of a credit for subsequent taxable years if deficiency procedures are initiated, requiring the taxpayer to provide necessary information to demonstrate eligibility. Effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Checklist for paid preparers to verify eligibility for refundable portion of the Child Tax Credit; penalty for failure to meet due diligence requirements. The Secretary of the Treasury must create a form for paid tax preparers to complete when claiming the refundable portion of the child tax credit. Failure to diligently determine eligibility for the credit will result in a $500 penalty. The amendment imposes a $500 penalty for failure to claim the child tax credit properly. The effective date is for taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
